text:
that feeling when you’re styling on the fly in the browser and you accidentally click a link…
<https://gph.is/1oKlNYU>
yea worst thing ever
BTW did you know you can make your changes persist
it’s pretty stinkin’ awesome but kind of a hidden feature
how do you do this sorcery of which you speak?
is there a link that explains that?
ahhhh googled and I’m going down that rabbit trail for the next 15 minutes lol

so there’s a couple methods but they revolve around the same thing.

So the trick is go to your sources tab

If you have your files locally(like if you’re working with git or something, you can add a folder to workspace) then it will use those local versions of the css files and whatnot and all of your changes take effect in those files
the other method I think was to go to the overrides section
you can then add a css file  - I think it provides a shortcut if you currently have an “inspector stylesheet” started (after adding some styles)
cool, thanks for the explanation :slightly_smiling_face:
trying to find the chrome update release that talks about how to do it
it made it sound easier than I just did
<https://egghead.io/lessons/chrome-persist-live-style-changes-in-the-browser-with-chrome-devtools-local-overrides>
THERE WE GO
that looks like a good article/video for it
does chrome have a tab for tracking changes like firefox?
can’t remember exactly how you do it but with the local overrides feature you can do that
somehow you can get a diff view
it's pretty handy if you get in the weeds using the dev tools to play with changes
i dont see a persist local overrides option for ff, though :disappointed:  that would be handy
yea so in chrome there’s a changes tab similar to Firefox but it feels a little clunky,atleast in this fake situation I’m trying to reproduce it in
That must have taken 50000000 hours to code. haha

So general random question, when you are connecting stylesheets to templates, do you do them on a per template basis or do you instead use the Settings > Website > Pages are to add your stylesheet consistently across the domain?

Back before DM2 I did use the domain wide stylesheets because for a little bit it was kind of a best practice. But after doing my first website redesign I realized that’s a bad practice that makes it a pain down  the road.

I use an included html file with all of my template specific includes. This file is loaded into the Head of all of my templates and is filled with requires for both js and css, and any html I might have to add to the head.

Anything module specific is required/linked at the module level.

Yea thats what im trying to get a sense of, I see the benefits of doing it both ways but for a client site, i feel it might be easier to do it a the domain wide level as that way if they ever create their own templates  they dont have to think about "what style sheets do I need to connect" or anything like that

personally I’ve always felt we need a “Template groups” feature which would allow adding linked assets to templates, but templates would be able to be part of a group. and templates could even be part of multiple groups
That way you could say have 1 group for OLD templates on a site, and a new group for a redesign
you could even have another group for landing pages - if you need different css/js for those.

Yea, when I review their site now, it looks like the last company they had did it from a domain level (they are only on the hs-sites domains, not real domain connected yet) so if I did anything, it would have to be on the `[portalId].<http://hs-sites.com|hs-sites.com>` domain to preview anyways because of the code on the `[businesname]-[portalId].<http://hs-sites.com|hs-sites.com>` domain
so i guess it really doesnt matter in the end since either way I have to use the other preview domain when building anyways or there will be other CSS injected
also, if you dont add the template level css, then when you preview the template, you dont see it (unless you use the preview with options)

Hello, how can I win HubSpot work? I am looking for some HubSpot work, I have 8+ years of experience in frontend development and also HubSpot development experience

Please provide pointers.

usually <@UD53A9UUR> fires a gun in the air and we battle to the death  for the opportunity to submit a proposal to a client.


joking - you said “win” and that’s what came to my head.

You can post that you’re available for work in the <#CBNDYJJAZ|jobs> channel.

you could create an upwork profile or other freelance/outsourcing tool.

Otherwise my suggestion - follow the inbound marketing method - but for yourself instead of a company(unless you’re finding work for your company of course)
I also recommend getting the CMS Developer Certification that builds client trust
i like the first idea
Also another idea - build for the HubSpot Marketplace
there is also this: <https://onthebench.io/become-a-service-provider/>
not sure how good it is

Thanks a ton for the help guys!
<@U7SL518D6> <@UD53A9UUR> :grin::+1:
just a curiosity, how do you all organize/ catalogue your custom modules so you can reuse on different portal.  particularly if you are on a team.
we have a HubSpot portal that is intended to hold the latest version of every module
do you have them displayed on a page for reference?
we have a bitbucket repo though and that’s the true source of truth for everything
yes we have a page for referencing them
cool.  trying to build something out for the design team to reference as well as make it easier for the developers
We currently have the problem of forgetting to sync from the bitbucket to the dev HubSpot portal. That’s kinda the flaw to this system
hmmm
wonder if you can use some like circleci
we keep maintaining and updating the modules and we do that in the repo but forget to sync it back to the hs portal. I would love to automate that somehow
how do you sync it now?
download and ftp?
FTP
yeah, you could automate that
have to make sure no errors in the code or it will be rejected, obviously
yea
I would love to have some kind of HubL testing type thing. Even just for <#CCQSQ2C6L|crankshaft>  it would be great
certainly would be.
maybe this docker thing will have some of that juice
which i am extremely excited about
:slightly_smiling_face:
a goal of mine for CrankShaft is to have a full testing setup so every time someone submits a PR automated tests could run to tell you if anything breaks.
yea excited for the docker thing too
that is a big project!
I'm aware. I'm also aware because its going to be a pain in the butt most of the responsibility of setting that up is on my shoulders
The other big challenge is that there aren't many devs in this community who are familiar with unit testing, so i dont have a whole lot of great minds to talk to about it
